segment.source: Configure Key Exchange (Main Mode) Settings (Windows 10)
segment.target: Configure Key Exchange (Main Mode) Settings (Windows 10)

segment.source: Configure Key Exchange (Main Mode) Settings
segment.target: Configure Key Exchange (Main Mode) Settings

segment.source: Configure Key Exchange (Main Mode) Settings
segment.target: Configure Key Exchange (Main Mode) Settings

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview
segment.target: Windows Server 2016 Technical Preview

segment.source: This procedure shows you how to configure the main mode key exchange settings used to secure the IPsec authentication traffic.
segment.target: This procedure shows you how to configure the main mode key exchange settings used to secure the IPsec authentication traffic.

segment.source: Administrative credentials
segment.target: Administrative credentials

segment.source: To complete these procedures, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.
segment.target: To complete these procedures, you must be a member of the Domain Administrators group, or otherwise be delegated permissions to modify the GPOs.

segment.source: To configure key exchange settings
segment.target: To configure key exchange settings

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management Console to Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management Console to Windows Firewall with Advanced Security.

segment.source: In the details pane on the main Windows Firewall with Advanced Security page, click Windows Firewall Properties.
segment.target: In the details pane on the main Windows Firewall with Advanced Security page, click Windows Firewall Properties.

segment.source: On the IPsec Settings tab, click Customize.
segment.target: On the IPsec Settings tab, click Customize.

segment.source: In the Key exchange (Main Mode) section, click Advanced, and then click Customize.
segment.target: In the Key exchange (Main Mode) section, click Advanced, and then click Customize.

segment.source: Select the security methods to be used to help protect the main mode negotiations between the two devices.
segment.target: Select the security methods to be used to help protect the main mode negotiations between the two devices.

segment.source: If the security methods displayed in the list are not what you want, then do the following:
segment.target: If the security methods displayed in the list are not what you want, then do the following:

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: In Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, or later, you can specify only one key exchange algorithm.
segment.target: In Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, or later, you can specify only one key exchange algorithm.

segment.source: This means that if you want to communicate by using IPsec with another device running Windows 8 or Windows Server 2012, then you must select the same key exchange algorithm on both devices.
segment.target: This means that if you want to communicate by using IPsec with another device running Windows 8 or Windows Server 2012, then you must select the same key exchange algorithm on both devices.

segment.source: Also, if you create a connection security rule that specifies an option that requires AuthIP instead of IKE, then only the one combination of the top integrity and encryption security method are used in the negotiation.
segment.target: Also, if you create a connection security rule that specifies an option that requires AuthIP instead of IKE, then only the one combination of the top integrity and encryption security method are used in the negotiation.

segment.source: Make sure that all of your devices that are running at least Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008 have the same methods at the top of the list and the same key exchange algorithm selected.
segment.target: Make sure that all of your devices that are running at least Windows Vista and Windows Server 2008 have the same methods at the top of the list and the same key exchange algorithm selected.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: When AuthIP is used, no Diffie-Hellman key exchange protocol is used.
segment.target: When AuthIP is used, no Diffie-Hellman key exchange protocol is used.

segment.source: Instead, when Kerberos V5 authentication is requested, the Kerberos V5 service ticket secret is used in place of a Diffie-Hellman value.
segment.target: Instead, when Kerberos V5 authentication is requested, the Kerberos V5 service ticket secret is used in place of a Diffie-Hellman value.

segment.source: When either certificate authentication or NTLM authentication is requested, a transport level security (TLS) session is established, and its secret is used in place of the Diffie-Hellman value.
segment.target: When either certificate authentication or NTLM authentication is requested, a transport level security (TLS) session is established, and its secret is used in place of the Diffie-Hellman value.

segment.source: This happens no matter which Diffie-Hellman key exchange protocol you select.
segment.target: This happens no matter which Diffie-Hellman key exchange protocol you select.

segment.source: Remove any of the security methods that you do not want by selecting the method and then clicking Remove.
segment.target: Remove any of the security methods that you do not want by selecting the method and then clicking Remove.

segment.source: Add any required security method combinations by clicking Add, selecting the appropriate encryption algorithm and integrity algorithm from the lists, and then clicking OK.
segment.target: Add any required security method combinations by clicking Add, selecting the appropriate encryption algorithm and integrity algorithm from the lists, and then clicking OK.

segment.source: Caution: We recommend that you do not include MD5 or DES in any combination.
segment.target: Caution: We recommend that you do not include MD5 or DES in any combination.

segment.source: They are included for backward compatibility only.
segment.target: They are included for backward compatibility only.

segment.source: After the list contains only the combinations you want, use the up and down arrows to the right of the list to arrange them in the order of preference.
segment.target: After the list contains only the combinations you want, use the up and down arrows to the right of the list to arrange them in the order of preference.

segment.source: The combination that appears first in the list is tried first, and so on.
segment.target: The combination that appears first in the list is tried first, and so on.

segment.source: From the list on the right, select the key exchange algorithm that you want to use.
segment.target: From the list on the right, select the key exchange algorithm that you want to use.

segment.source: Caution: We recommend that you do not use Diffie-Hellman Group 1.
segment.target: Caution: We recommend that you do not use Diffie-Hellman Group 1.

segment.source: It is included for backward compatibility only.
segment.target: It is included for backward compatibility only.

segment.source: In Key lifetime (in minutes), type the number of minutes.
segment.target: In Key lifetime (in minutes), type the number of minutes.

segment.source: When the specified number of minutes has elapsed, any IPsec operation between the two devices requires a new key.
segment.target: When the specified number of minutes has elapsed, any IPsec operation between the two devices requires a new key.

segment.source: Note: You need to balance performance with security requirements.
segment.target: Note: You need to balance performance with security requirements.

segment.source: Although a shorter key lifetime results in better security, it also reduces performance.
segment.target: Although a shorter key lifetime results in better security, it also reduces performance.

segment.source: In Key lifetime (in sessions), type the number of sessions.
segment.target: In Key lifetime (in sessions), type the number of sessions.

segment.source: After the specified number of quick mode sessions have been created within the security association protected by this key, IPsec requires a new key.
segment.target: After the specified number of quick mode sessions have been created within the security association protected by this key, IPsec requires a new key.

segment.source: Click OK three times to save your settings.
segment.target: Click OK three times to save your settings.
